qualification_name: Bachelor of Computer & Information Sciences and Bachelor of Science
prescriptor: Extends individual software development skills into a team environment. Students are exposed to common and emergent practices in the field and introduced to a range of tools that support development processes and practices.

qualification_name: Bachelor of Computer & Information Sciences and Bachelor of Science
prescriptor: Provides an insight into the Object Oriented paradigm and methods of data and process modelling. Building on the broader context of Software, Information and Systems Engineering, contemporary methods used in analysis and design are covered and the techniques used to produce optimised models of data and processes are detailed.

qualification_name: Bachelor of Computer & Information Sciences and Bachelor of Science
prescriptor: Provides students with the essential concepts, principles, and techniques of database management systems. Specifically, the paper provides an in-depth understanding of data modelling and database design concepts. The retrieval language will be covered in detail. The balanced approach of theory and practice will provide students with a better understanding of the issues and problems involved in database design and development.

qualification_name: Bachelor of Computer & Information Sciences and Bachelor of Science
prescriptor: An introduction to the design and construction of object- oriented software. It will extend individual design and programming skills developed in earlier programming papers, with an emphasis on the quality, modularity and reusability of the software developed. The paper will introduce current techniques used in software development that allow the goals of software development projects to be realised.

qualification_name: Bachelor of Computer & Information Sciences and Bachelor of Science
prescriptor: Covers database design from a performance perspective. Presents a complete view of the Database Design process from Requirements Analysis to Database Deployment on an actual Database server. Issues such as Data Storage, Security, Concurrency Control, Query Optimisation, Access Paths, Application Tuning and Data Warehousing are covered in depth. Overall, the course develops the ability to deal with the technical aspects of database administration in an enterprise scale database system.

qualification_name: Bachelor of Computer & Information Sciences and Bachelor of Science
prescriptor: An application of major bioinformatics tools to address problems of central dogma and proteomics is presented.  Main sequence and pathways databases are introduced and ontology tools used for searching the databases will be demonstrated. An introduction to comparative genomics technologies, applications and challenges is also presented.

qualification_name: Bachelor of Computer & Information Sciences and Bachelor of Science
prescriptor: A general overview of biochemistry: the properties of enzymes; photosynthesis; metabolism of lipids and carbohydrates; nitrogen and amino acid metabolism; nucleic acids and protein synthesis. Cell membrane and wall structure and function.

qualification_name: Bachelor of Computer & Information Sciences and Bachelor of Science
prescriptor: An understanding of how the growth and activities of micro-organisms in natural environments such as soil, water and air, affect peoples quality of life. The design of acceptable scientific solutions to problems in pollution control, public health, agriculture and resource recovery.

qualification_name: Bachelor of Computer & Information Sciences and Bachelor of Science
prescriptor: The utilisation of micro-organisms and microbial processes to produce economically important products such as food, industrial chemicals and pharmaceuticals; understanding of the technologies associated with commercial production of microbial metabolites; the relevance of the growth and activity of micro-organisms to the national economy and to our quality of life.

qualification_name: Bachelor of Computer & Information Sciences and Bachelor of Science
prescriptor: An overview of the processes of DNA replication, transcription and translation, transformation and transduction; the polymerase chain reaction, restriction endonucleases and sequencing.

qualification_name: Bachelor of Computer & Information Sciences and Bachelor of Science
prescriptor: An understanding of the role of micro-organisms in food spoilage, food preservation and food borne disease; the practice of food microbiology.

qualification_name: Bachelor of Computer & Information Sciences and Bachelor of Science
prescriptor: An investigation into a selected area whether that be a specific problem domain, or an area of business opportunity.  The project is typically an original investigation but considerable flexibility is allowed.  Typically projects will involve either commercial software development for live clients, commercial research and development projects on behalf of live clients, or supervised research projects into selected areas of interest.

qualification_name: Bachelor of Computer & Information Sciences and Bachelor of Science
prescriptor: The aim of this paper is to understand the nature of intelligent systems and how such a system may be implemented.

qualification_name: Bachelor of Computer & Information Sciences and Bachelor of Science
prescriptor: Furthers understanding of the factors (psychological, ergonomic, organisational, social etc) that determine how people operate and make use of computer technology effectively.

qualification_name: Bachelor of Computer & Information Sciences and Bachelor of Science
prescriptor: Provides students with the core competencies of project management together with an appreciation of professional ethics and practice related to the introduction and life cycle of information systems and services in organisations.

qualification_name: Bachelor of Computer & Information Sciences and Bachelor of Science
prescriptor: Reviews the advancements of methods and applications in computational biology.  Data analysis, data management, processing and knowledge discovery from bio-data are covered.  Genomics expression data such as microarray gene expression and decision support systems are included covering application areas of Science and Engineering, Medicine, Health, Agriculture, Horticulture, Bio-protection, brain research, ICT, and business.

qualification_name: Bachelor of Computer & Information Sciences and Bachelor of Science
prescriptor: Examines the relationships and capabilities of Information Systems in global information economies. The analysis, design and implementation of IS is examined, along with the use of enabling technologies to engineer Information Systems across diverse organisations.

qualification_name: Bachelor of Computer & Information Sciences and Bachelor of Science
prescriptor: An investigation of a defined topic in a supervised programme of readings.

qualification_name: Bachelor of Computer & Information Sciences and Bachelor of Science
prescriptor: Introduces students to the exciting world of Data Mining. Organisations have, over time, accumulated vast amounts of valuable data which, when exploited appropriately will give them a significant competitive advantage over their rivals who merely "crunch" data. Data Mining is an area that has come of age - well proven techniques and tools are widely available. Covers popular mining techniques as well as providing specific hands-on experience using a publicly available tool.

qualification_name: Bachelor of Computer & Information Sciences and Bachelor of Science
prescriptor: The application of scientific and engineering principles to the processing of material by biological agents (i.e. microbial plant, animal cells and enzymes); the processing of biological materials such as food, medicine and chemicals; how a living cell performs a specific useful task in a predictable and controllable way.

qualification_name: Bachelor of Computer & Information Sciences and Bachelor of Science
prescriptor: An introduction to the principles and applications of molecular genetics, gene manipulation and related technologies.

qualification_name: Bachelor of Computer & Information Sciences and Bachelor of Science
prescriptor: An understanding of the microbial ecology of foods and the role of micro-organisms in food production; problems associated with sampling and micro-biological analysis of foods;  interpretation of micro-biological data; development of an assurance programme in food preparation and food manufacture.

qualification_name: Bachelor of Computer and Information Sciences
prescriptor: Study skills workshop

qualification_name: Bachelor of Computer and Information Sciences
prescriptor: Skills and capabilities based on theoretical knowledge in the areas of written, oral, interpersonal and group communication. The content of the course is at all stages made relevant to the students needs both for their course of study and their role in the workplace.

qualification_name: Bachelor of Computer and Information Sciences
prescriptor: An introduction to the basics of computer programming to equip students for a career in any branch of IT, the sciences, data analysis or engineering. The fundamentals of writing, designing and testing programs will be developed.

qualification_name: Bachelor of Computer and Information Sciences
prescriptor: Provides a wide-ranging, multidisciplinary introduction to the evolution and application of increasingly complex and powerful computer systems (and other forms of digital technology) with particular emphasis on their impact on society.

qualification_name: Bachelor of Computer and Information Sciences
prescriptor: Provides an introduction to IT infrastructure concepts in order to enable students to understand computer systems architecture for effective configuration and use. Concepts of single user, multi-user, centralised, and operating systems are covered, along with applications and end-user computing.

qualification_name: Bachelor of Computer and Information Sciences
prescriptor: Introduces the process of program design and implementation using object-oriented programming, with particular emphasis on applications from Computer Science and engineering technology.

qualification_name: Bachelor of Computer and Information Sciences
prescriptor: Presents an integrated approach to data communications and computer networking principles, building on IT infrastructure concepts. These concepts are applied in a network environment starting with the application layer and progressing through to the data link layer.

qualification_name: Bachelor of Computer and Information Sciences
prescriptor: Introduces programming concepts through the use of structured scripting to move and manipulate multimedia objects, such as images, audio and video files. Aspects of interpreting system feedback, identifying errors and developing coding best practice are also covered.  This elective paper provides students with an opportunity to learn and practice programming through structured activities that can be built on in more advanced programming papers.

qualification_name: Bachelor of Computer and Information Sciences
prescriptor: To provide the knowledge and skills required to build a scalable switched and routed computer network.

qualification_name: Bachelor of Computer and Information Sciences
prescriptor: Introduces the process of program design and implementation using object-oriented programming, with particular emphasis on applications from Computer Science and engineering technology.

qualification_name: Bachelor of Computer and Information Sciences
prescriptor: Introduces the process of program design and implementation using object-oriented programming, with particular emphasis on applications from Computer Science and engineering technology.

qualification_name: Bachelor of Computer and Information Sciences
prescriptor: An introduction to enterprise information systems, the relevant processes, controls and reports in an information technology environment, and Information System development methodologies.

qualification_name: Bachelor of Computer and Information Sciences
prescriptor: Provides an introduction to the mathematical concepts required for an understanding of the analysis of data and applications in computing, science, and engineering. Topics include: sets, functions, series, limits, calculus, probability and statistics.

qualification_name: Bachelor of Computer and Information Sciences
prescriptor: Gives the student an understanding of differential and integral calculus, and develops the ability to formulate and solve models of simple engineering and scientific systems.

qualification_name: Bachelor of Computer and Information Sciences
prescriptor: Gives the student a solid foundation in algebra and discrete mathematics, providing essential background for further study in many fields of Science and Engineering, particularly those utilizing ideas from Mathematics or Computer Science.

qualification_name: Bachelor of Computer and Information Sciences
prescriptor: An introduction to applied statistics. Provides techniques for describing and summarising a data set. Delivers an understanding of how to use a sample to infer the properties of the population it was taken from. Students in this course also learn how to use statistical software to undertake descriptive analysis as well as perform statistical inference.

qualification_name: Bachelor of Computer and Information Sciences
prescriptor: Provides students with the core competencies of project management in an information technology context. A range of IT project management methodologies and approaches are compared. Some proven practices and supporting tools and techniques are further investigated, particularly with regard to planning, monitoring, estimating and implementing. Expected standards of professionalism and ethics will be highlighted.

qualification_name: Bachelor of Computer and Information Sciences
prescriptor: Provides an introduction to IT Service Science and its role in the development and provision of high quality IT services. The foundations of high quality services are covered, including standard procedures, techniques and tools. Students will gain IT service and operations orientated skills.

qualification_name: Bachelor of Computer and Information Sciences
prescriptor: Extends individual software development skills into a team environment. Students are exposed to common and emergent practices in the field and introduced to a range of tools that support development processes and practices.

qualification_name: Bachelor of Computer and Information Sciences
prescriptor: An introduction to the design and construction of object- oriented software. It will extend individual design and programming skills developed in earlier programming papers, with an emphasis on the quality, modularity and reusability of the software developed. The paper will introduce current techniques used in software development that allow the goals of software development projects to be realised.

qualification_name: Bachelor of Computer and Information Sciences
prescriptor: An introduction to the design and construction of object- oriented software. It will extend individual design and programming skills developed in earlier programming papers, with an emphasis on the quality, modularity and reusability of the software developed. The paper will introduce current techniques used in software development that allow the goals of software development projects to be realised.

qualification_name: Bachelor of Computer and Information Sciences
prescriptor: To lay a foundation for the use and understanding of information from a computational perspective This paper will prepare students to identify sources of information, their advantages and limitations and the application of information to real-world problems. The transformation of data to knowledge represents a key objective of this paper.

qualification_name: Bachelor of Computer and Information Sciences
prescriptor: Addresses security technology and systems; basic cryptography and public key infrastructure, physical security, logical security, access controls, securing networks, network operations, systems, databases and applications, mobile and wireless security, web-services security, and security strategies for e-commerce. The intrinsic relationship between security technologies, ethics, legal and regulatory requirements, forensics and fraud, business strategy, and risk management is addressed.

qualification_name: Bachelor of Computer and Information Sciences
prescriptor: Issues, skills and strategies associated with providing core services over a network in a multi user environment. The student will also learn about fine tuning of networked systems for optimum delivery in terms of security, cost and speed.

qualification_name: Bachelor of Computer and Information Sciences
prescriptor: Theoretical and practical skills for the utilisation of mathematical structures and algorithms for handling data that are essential in computational mathematics and computer science. Static and dynamic structures for data, cloning data, mathematical concepts of iteration and recursion, analysis of performance and complexity, data searching and data sorting algorithms, mathematical logic and formal grammars.

qualification_name: Bachelor of Computer and Information Sciences
prescriptor: Algorithmic analysis, concurrency algorithms, design patterns, design techniques, advanced data structures, graph algorithms, numerical algorithms.

qualification_name: Bachelor of Computer and Information Sciences
prescriptor: A practical foundation in high-level computer graphics programming and a comprehensive overview of proven graphics algorithms and software techniques is presented with a focus on those techniques that have become common currency in the field of interactive computer graphics.

qualification_name: Bachelor of Computer and Information Sciences
prescriptor: An introduction to the logical and combinatorial tools and methods used in mathematics and computer science, with an emphasis on axiomatic systems, combinatorial principles, and automated reasoning.

qualification_name: Bachelor of Computer and Information Sciences
prescriptor: To provide the knowledge and skills required to build a scalable switched and routed Wide Area Network.

qualification_name: Bachelor of Computer and Information Sciences
prescriptor: A practical foundation in high-level computer graphics programming and a comprehensive overview of proven graphics algorithms and software techniques is presented with a focus on those techniques that have become common currency in the field of interactive computer graphics.

qualification_name: Bachelor of Computer and Information Sciences
prescriptor: Provides students with the essential concepts, principles, and techniques of database management systems. Specifically, the paper provides an in-depth understanding of data modelling and database design concepts. The retrieval language will be covered in detail. The balanced approach of theory and practice will provide students with a better understanding of the issues and problems involved in database design and development.

qualification_name: Bachelor of Computer and Information Sciences
prescriptor: Covers database design from a performance perspective. Presents a complete view of the Database Design process from Requirements Analysis to Database Deployment on an actual Database server. Issues such as Data Storage, Security, Concurrency Control, Query Optimisation, Access Paths, Application Tuning and Data Warehousing are covered in depth. Overall, the course develops the ability to deal with the technical aspects of database administration in an enterprise scale database system.

qualification_name: Bachelor of Computer and Information Sciences
prescriptor: Focuses on skills required to identify a user's information technology solution requirements: to investigate and evaluate suitable solutions including software, platform and vendors, to plan the acquisition of a solution, to identify training requirements, and to plan a training programme using various delivery methods including flexible/blended delivery.

qualification_name: Bachelor of Computer and Information Sciences
prescriptor: The elements of actuarial mathematics: securities, annuities, mortality laws, life annuities, life insurance policy values.

qualification_name: Bachelor of Computer and Information Sciences
prescriptor: Provides an introduction to a branch of statistics that deals with the study of chance. Delivers access to a range of techniques for modelling and analysing probability problems in real-life settings.

qualification_name: Bachelor of Computer and Information Sciences
prescriptor: A study of statistical methods suitable for a range of applications in science, engineering and business.

qualification_name: Bachelor of Computer and Information Sciences
prescriptor: An introduction to forecasting in business and economics using statistical models. Making predictions from data that arise sequentially in time (e.g. annual electricity production, unemployment rates, share prices, global temperature series). Topics include forecasting strategies, detecting trends, autoregressive models, and simulation.

qualification_name: Bachelor of Computer and Information Sciences
prescriptor: Language and vision are fundamental to human perception and cognition, yet there is relatively little understanding of how the two interact or operate together at a system level to aid learning and recognition. This paper covers fundamental and advanced aspects of language (especially text) and vision from an artificial intelligence perspective. The primary focus is on practical algorithms, tools and systems of text, vision intelligence, as well as their performance evaluation. Techniques of representing information in semi-formal languages such as Standard Generalized Markup Language (SGML) and free text are compared. The issues associated with representation and extraction of information encapsulated in textual and visual formats, such as the semantic unit perceived as an event, will be explored. Examples of text and visual modelling techniques such as probabilistic and vector models will be used to illustrate AI applications.

qualification_name: Bachelor of Computer and Information Sciences
prescriptor: Provides an overview of the fundamentals of nature inspired computing (NIC), particularly in the fields of evolutionary algorithms, swarm intelligence, artificial life, DNA computing and quantum computing. Real world applications in optimization, simulation and modeling will be introduced in workshops and recent advances presented and analysed.

qualification_name: Bachelor of Computer and Information Sciences
prescriptor: An investigation into a selected area whether that be a specific problem domain, or an area of business opportunity. The project is typically an original investigation but considerable flexibility is allowed. Typically projects will involve software or systems development for business clients, commercial research and development projects on behalf of clients, or supervised research projects in selected areas specific to the Major of the student.

qualification_name: Bachelor of Computer and Information Sciences
prescriptor: An investigation into a selected area whether that be a specific problem domain, or an area of business opportunity. The project is typically an original investigation but considerable flexibility is allowed. Typically projects will involve software or systems development for business clients, commercial research and development projects on behalf of clients, or supervised research projects in selected areas specific to the Major of the student.

qualification_name: Bachelor of Computer and Information Sciences
prescriptor: An investigation into a selected area whether that be a specific problem domain, or an area of business opportunity. The project is typically an original investigation but considerable flexibility is allowed. Typically projects will involve software or systems development for business clients, commercial research and development projects on behalf of clients, or supervised research projects in selected areas specific to the major of the student.

qualification_name: Bachelor of Computer and Information Sciences
prescriptor: An investigation of a defined topic in a supervised programme of readings.

qualification_name: Bachelor of Computer and Information Sciences
prescriptor: An investigation into a selected area whether that be a specific problem domain, or an area of business opportunity.  The project is typically an original investigation but considerable flexibility is allowed.  Typically projects will involve either commercial software development for live clients, commercial research and development projects on behalf of live clients, or supervised research projects into selected areas of interest.

qualification_name: Bachelor of Computer and Information Sciences
prescriptor: A practical foundation in game programming, using a variety of game development tools and programming libraries, and deploying games on a variety of platforms.

qualification_name: Bachelor of Computer and Information Sciences
prescriptor: A rigorous exploration into the Theory of Computer Science providing a mathematically sound presentation of the theory of computer science including formal languages and models of computation, as well as an introduction to computational complexity.

qualification_name: Bachelor of Computer and Information Sciences
prescriptor: Surveys the theoretical and practical aspects of modern programming languages, including their design and implementation, program translation, virtual machines, and different programming pradigms.

qualification_name: Bachelor of Computer and Information Sciences
prescriptor: Investigates the design and implementation of distributed systems, including contemporary technologies such as Java Enterprise Edition and .NET, as well as the development of mobile systems.

qualification_name: Bachelor of Computer and Information Sciences
prescriptor: This course reviews the advancement in data communications and networking supporting distributed systems incorporating components from current Networking protocols and products.. It applies relevant theoretical models for the evaluation, selection and deployment of advanced network technologies providing specified services.

qualification_name: Bachelor of Computer and Information Sciences
prescriptor: Provides an in-depth understanding of LAN, WAN and Wireless security focusing on the functionality available and configuration of network and link layers.

qualification_name: Bachelor of Computer and Information Sciences
prescriptor: Provides an in-depth understanding of LAN, WAN and Wireless security focusing on the functionality available and configuration of network and link layers.

qualification_name: Bachelor of Computer and Information Sciences
prescriptor: The aim of this paper is to understand the nature of intelligent systems and how such a system may be implemented.

qualification_name: Bachelor of Computer and Information Sciences
prescriptor: A holistic view of how information security is managed in an organisation, examining its relationship with laws, ethics, culture, standards. Includes the examination of the frameworks, processes, and measures as well as practical problems involved in building secure operational environments for businesses and individual users. Develops the ability to design secure information technology environments.

qualification_name: Bachelor of Computer and Information Sciences
prescriptor: Furthers understanding of the factors (psychological, ergonomic, organisational, social etc) that determine how people operate and make use of computer technology effectively.

qualification_name: Bachelor of Computer and Information Sciences
prescriptor: Provides students with the core competencies of project management together with an appreciation of professional ethics and practice related to the introduction and life cycle of information systems and services in organisations.

qualification_name: Bachelor of Computer and Information Sciences
prescriptor: Extends the students' knowledge of data communications and internetworking over the World Wide Web, to cover issues associated with development of applications in this environment. Emphasis is upon the analysis, design and development of web-based applications for a variety of purposes using current tools and techniques.

qualification_name: Bachelor of Computer and Information Sciences
prescriptor: Introduces students to the exciting world of Data Mining. Organisations have, over time, accumulated vast amounts of valuable data which, when exploited appropriately will give them a significant competitive advantage over their rivals who merely "crunch" data. Data Mining is an area that has come of age - well proven techniques and tools are widely available. Covers popular mining techniques as well as providing specific hands-on experience using a publicly available tool.

qualification_name: Bachelor of Computer and Information Sciences
prescriptor: Demonstrates effective analysis of the role of IT in health care and the Primary, Secondary and Public health levels. Identifies the appropriate use of technologies involved in health informatics including coding, diagnosis and communication systems as well as the electronic medical record. Topics include ethical and practical considerations for the effective use of health informatics along with the use of evidence to guide practice.

qualification_name: Bachelor of Computer and Information Sciences
prescriptor: This paper aims to further develop your understanding of the concepts and methods required for the construction of large software intensive systems. The paper develops a broader understanding of the discipline of software engineering to provide exposure to the full range of techniques and processes associated with the development of complex software intensive systems.

qualification_name: Bachelor of Computer and Information Sciences
paper_name: From Perception to Technology: 3-D Display and Haptic Systems
prescriptor: Describes a broad range of emerging creative 3-D display and interaction interfaces (including haptics) framing this discussion within an evolutionary context and by frequent reference to human cognitive, problem solving, and sensory processes. A research-infused curriculum is adopted in this transdisciplinary paper.

qualification_name: Bachelor of Computer and Information Sciences
prescriptor: Focuses on skills required to identify a user's information technology solution requirements: to investigate and evaluate suitable solutions including software, platforms, and vendors, to plan the acquisition of a solution, to critically analyse the models and methodologies used in the requirements analysis and acquisition process.

qualification_name: Bachelor of Computer and Information Sciences
prescriptor: Examines the practice and theory of IT Services Management with a focus on industry best practices in managing information technology in an organisation. Such practices are put in context through the presentation of an overall framework for aligning IT strategies with business strategies, monitoring, evaluating and improving IT operations performance, and auditing the relevant processes.

qualification_name: Bachelor of Computer and Information Sciences
prescriptor: A critical analysis of the service techniques and procedures required to provide supervision, technical support, IT operations services and customer service in an IT operations environment.

qualification_name: Bachelor of Computer and Information Sciences
prescriptor: Examines the relationships and capabilities of Information Systems in global information economies. The analysis, design and implementation of IS is examined, along with the use of enabling technologies to engineer Information Systems across diverse organisations.

qualification_name: Bachelor of Computer and Information Sciences
prescriptor: The focus of this paper is the application of stochastic models to analyse real-life scenarios.  Key stochastic processes are studied via their mathematical properties and simulation. Models are fitted to data taken from a range of applications.

qualification_name: Bachelor of Computer and Information Sciences
prescriptor: An introduction to data management for analytics suitable for applications in business, finance, industry, and government.  Topics include: querying, cleaning, manipulating, and displaying data;   programming skills and methods suitable for handling large data sets.

qualification_name: Bachelor of Computer and Information Sciences
prescriptor: Collection and analysis of data in an industrial and business context. Control charts, experimental design, samples and surveys. Analysis of data using analytics software.
Engineering workshop practice.

To provide students with the ability to demonstrate mathematical skills, concepts and understanding in precalculus and calculus and to select and use appropriate mathematical techniques in engineering related problems.

Construction design modelling/simulation essentials. Introduces the application of various software in building LCA (design, construction and maintenance). Examines the basis of component-based simulation and cyber-collaboration among different building construction team members. Explores the challenges that arise from the interactions between design and construction. Develops an initial understanding of how sustainable outcomes are engineered into the design process.
An introduction to the design and construction process for low rise domestic buildings. All levels of the building are considered from the foundations to the roof.

Explores the properties, behaviours, performance and constraints of commonly used construction materials such as timber, steel, concrete, polymers and composites. Evaluates the application, processing and environmental impacts of different materials with a focus on sustainability and waste minimisation.
An introduction to the fundamentals of analogue electronics including the ideas of modeling non-linear device characteristics.
The fundamental principles of electrical engineering. Applies the principles, theories and problems of electrostatics, electromagnetics and electric circuits.
Develops engineering students' understanding of the characteristics and behaviour of digital systems.
To provide the knowledge and skills required to build a scalable switched and routed computer network.

Provides the engineering knowledge and skills necessary to understand the hardware and software operation of personal computers, including hardware, operating system software, networking, trouble-shooting and basic software packages.
A foundation for the understanding of electrical power including 3-phase calculations for balanced and unbalanced loads, harmonics in power systems, the PU system, and AC magnetics.
To provide a basic understanding in the fundamentals of Electrical Machines, including Induction Motor and DC Motors.

To introduce the student to lighting by providing the basic knowledge of and skills in the nature of light, units of measurements, the production and control of light and visual appraisal. The module provides the student with the principles which are the foundation of illumination engineering.

This paper introduces the fundamentals of telecommunications: principles of information theory as it applies in digital encoding and modulation; telecommunications network structures and transmission engineering.
This paper provides an intermediate knowledge of the concepts used in measurement and control systems for engineers.
To introduce the concept of a programmable logic controller, including programming methods and types, analog and digital input/output and external interconnection using bus systems.
The fundamental principles of electrical engineering. Applies the principles, theories and problems of electrostatics, electromagnetics and electric circuits.

Introduces students to engineering design practice and the responsibilities of the professional engineer in supporting a sustainable future. Develops the skills and processes required to effectively communicate in an engineering design solution using a variety of media. Provides an opportunity to create concept solutions to an open-ended problem using standard components.
Gives the student an understanding of differential and integral calculus, and develops the ability to formulate and solve models of simple engineering and scientific systems.
Provides the student a variety of mathematical techniques, and develops the ability to formulate and solve models of simple engineering and scientific systems.
An introduction to the basic concepts, principles and technology of thermodynamics, energy, fluid mechanics and heat transfer.

The basic principles of structures and properties (mechanical, electrochemical and electrical) of solids as well as testing methods for property evaluation. Develops an understanding of how microstructures affect properties of solid materials. Based on this understanding, engineering materials (metallic alloys, ceramics, polymers and composites) can be properly selected for various applications and the principle of materials selection will be introduced.
The principles of static mechanics including simple selection applications based on accepted design standards.
The principles of mechanical dynamics including simple calculations and selection applications based on accepted design standards.
An introduction to technical computing packages used by engineers (such as Microsoft Excel, MATLAB, LabVIEW and R), general programming techniques and software development methodologies.
Introduces the process of program design and implementation using object-oriented programming, with particular emphasis on applications from Computer Science and engineering technology.
Introduces the process of program design and implementation using object-oriented programming, with particular emphasis on applications from Computer Science and engineering technology.

An introduction to computer programming for engineering applications using the C and C++ programming languages, including program design, input/output, data types, flow control, functions, arrays, strings, pointers, disk file input/output, classes and objects. Console and Windows GUI programs are developed. Matlab is used to construct a simple engineering model.

Gives the student a solid foundation in algebra and discrete mathematics, providing essential background for further study in many fields of Science and Engineering, particularly those utilizing ideas from Mathematics or Computer Science.

Provides an introduction to IT Service Science and its role in the development and provision of high quality IT services. The foundations of high quality services are covered, including standard procedures, techniques and tools. Students will gain IT service and operations orientated skills.

Extends individual software development skills into a team environment. Students are exposed to common and emergent practices in the field and introduced to a range of tools that support development processes and practices.

Issues, skills and strategies associated with providing core services over a network in a multi user environment. The student will also learn about fine tuning of networked systems for optimum delivery in terms of security, cost and speed.

Theoretical and practical skills for the utilisation of mathematical structures and algorithms for handling data that are essential in computational mathematics and computer science. Static and dynamic structures for data, cloning data, mathematical concepts of iteration and recursion, analysis of performance and complexity, data searching and data sorting algorithms, mathematical logic and formal grammars.
Algorithmic analysis, concurrency algorithms, design patterns, design techniques, advanced data structures, graph algorithms, numerical algorithms.

A practical foundation in high-level computer graphics programming and a comprehensive overview of proven graphics algorithms and software techniques is presented with a focus on those techniques that have become common currency in the field of interactive computer graphics.

Planning methods and tools are introduced, developing the relationship between planning and control and productivity. Professional responsibilities of engineers in Aotearoa New Zealand are considered, including health and safety legislation, the Treaty of Waitangi, ethics and professional practice. Risk management in the context of construction engineering is considered as part of the paper.

Construction technology on medium span, and low-rise commercial buildings. Develops a detailed knowledge of the main materials and structural systems used in buildings, ranging from foundations to roof construction systems. Provides grounding in structural analysis of timber, steel and concrete structures. Indigenous engineering concepts and materials are introduced in the context of Aotearoa New Zealand.

Construction cost planning, estimating and analysis. The application and interpretation of construction cost data sources, standard forms of cost analysis, estimating and tendering. A critical analysis of procurement methods, the effects that procurement has on costs, pricing, bidding strategy and contractor's cash flow, in the context of the economic sustainability of construction projects.

The fundamental principles and application of human factors engineering in the context of design applications in the built environment. This include issues of indoor air quality; plant and tool design; design of warnings; display and control loops; work physiology and biomechanics. This introductory paper will build to a whole-of-system analysis and redesign exercise.

Introduces the field of resilience as it relates to the roles of engineer and manager in relevant sectors. Explores the origins of the field, differing perspectives and practical management strategies through group discussion of case studies and individual analyses. Introduces tacit and explicit elements of Maori / indigenous approaches to resilience in materials and systems.

A critical evaluation of different types of building inspections including planned maintenance surveys, energy assessments, access and fire risk assessments. The principles and application of dilapidation procedures, professional practice and codes of conduct in the construction industry.

A critical evaluation of the theory and practice of safety management in the construction industry. Provides an overview of the key aspects of 'safety management', including health and safety problems associated with the construction industry, and safety laws in New Zealand and the wider global context.
A critical evaluation of contemporary asset and facilities management practice and the scope and context of the facilities management role.

Provides a broad based knowledge in technological areas related to ancillary building services. This includes fire detection, structured cabling, security, communication, lifts and escalators, and control systems.

To introduce the student to the development of a technical project including time management, electronic construction techniques and materials, co-operative working, documentation, reporting and presentation skills.
The operation and design of circuit models used in industrial processes.
Builds on the major areas of electronic engineering taught in earlier papers.

Introduces the student to the architecture and function of microcontrollers. Skills in the analysis and design of simple microcontroller based systems including hardware and software are developed. A high level language and a development environment will be used in the practical work and project based work.
Introduces students to the organisation and architecture of computer systems, including the standard von Neumann model and contemporary architectural concepts.
To create a complete embedded system from the initial design, functional and technical descriptions to the final electronic circuit, structure diagram and C code.
To provide the knowledge and skills required to build a scalable switched and routed Wide Area Network.
Computer engineering skills to analyze Linux based computing performance; configure hardware and software, solve hardware and software faults.

A foundation for the understanding of power electronics, including the modern devices used today, the typologies, waveforms, calculations and nuances of AD-DC, DC-AC, AC-AC and DC-DC conversion. Heating Control is presented, and methods of AC Motor Control and DC Motor Control are presented along with practical considerations.
To provide the learner with an understanding of the requirements for electrical installations in industrial and commercial buildings.

Application of advanced illumination engineering: general lighting measurements; physiology and functional parameters of the eye; photometric data and reports; lighting designs; characteristics and performance of lamps, control gear and luminaries.
To develop an understanding, learn and apply the principles of telecommunications technologies and systems as used in practical enterprise networks.

An introduction to the principles and techniques in radio frequency engineering; behaviour of components and materials at radio frequencies; oscillator circuits; tuned circuits; RF filter circuits; RF amplifier circuits; amplifier classes, configurations and stability.

An introduction to the IEC 6113-3 programming languages. Implementation of a SCADA (supervisory control and data acquisition) system and programming of touch screen panels; design test and configuration of a PLC level network (ethernet); advanced programming techniques using advanced mathematics and analog functions.
The fundamental principles and practice of management applied to a wide range of engineering situations. Develops an understanding of the structures and functions of engineering organisations.
Develops an understanding of advanced calculus, and the ability to formulate and solve models of complex engineering systems.

This paper will introduce the student to a systematic approach to engineering design with a four-phase, iterative design process of Planning, Concept Design, Embodiment Design and Detailing. Design strategies, including problem decomposition and solution synthesis, will be used to by student teams or individually to create robust & sustainable solutions to complex engineering problems.  Students will demonstrate their comprehension of engineering science principles and materials knowledge through their application to the analysis and synthesis of systems and parts.  CAD and CAE skills will be further developed and aspects of project management will be introduced, e.g. cooperative working, time management, documentation, reporting, and presentation skills.

To provide an understanding of the principles of fluid statics and dynamics, and use them to solve typical fluid mechanics problems.  To also provide the ability to select appropriate pumps, fans and compressors for engineering applications.
To provide students with an understanding of the principles of operations management, including reliability engineering and quality management, in the manufacturing environment.

Introduces a broad spectrum of manufacturing techniques and is designed to give an understanding of the working principles of the machinery and processes as used in manufacturing products. The importance of efficiency and costing is emphasised.

The application of mechanical engineering principles, design philosophies and design methodologies to moderately complex strength problems. The principles covered include failure mechanisms and, loading analysis of materials used in beams, columns and joints.

To enable students to solve complex machinery dynamics problems involving balancing, noise, lubrication systems and power transmission through clutches, brakes, bearings, belts, chains, gearboxes and flywheels.

paper_name: Computer Aided Design and Manufacturing - CAD/CAM
prescriptor: Extends the students knowledge on relevant engineering applications in the field of Computer Aided Design (CAD), Computer Numerical Control (CNC) and Computer Aided Manufacturing (CAM). Introduces Computer Aided Engineering (CAE) analysis tools, such as how to evaluate a dynamic operation.

Gives students a sound basic knowledge of thermodynamic principles -  including gas laws, measurement of pressure and temperature, mass and energy conservation and energy sources in the New Zealand context - and the mechanisms of heat transfer including the uses of heat exchangers.

Provides students with the essential concepts, principles, and techniques of database management systems. Specifically, the paper provides an in-depth understanding of data modelling and database design concepts. The retrieval language will be covered in detail. The balanced approach of theory and practice will provide students with a better understanding of the issues and problems involved in database design and development.
A practical foundation in game programming, using a variety of game development tools and programming libraries, and deploying games on a variety of platforms.
Investigates the design and implementation of distributed systems, including contemporary technologies such as Java Enterprise Edition and .NET, as well as the development of mobile systems.

This course reviews the advancement in data communications and networking supporting distributed systems incorporating components from current Networking protocols and products.. It applies relevant theoretical models for the evaluation, selection and deployment of advanced network technologies providing specified services.
Provides an in-depth understanding of LAN, WAN and Wireless security focusing on the functionality available and configuration of network and link layers.
Provides an in-depth understanding of LAN, WAN and Wireless security focusing on the functionality available and configuration of network and link layers.

The specification and design of HVAC systems in the context of highly serviced buildings. This includes aspects of environmental impact, life cycle costing, installation sequence and maintenance. Students will develop an understanding of relevant standards and design codes.

A critical evaluation of construction procurement and the legal framework in the New Zealand construction industry. Examines the standard form of construction procurement (traditional, design build, management forms) for construction projects. Develops the connectivity between current resource management practice and the wider context of the Treaty of Waitangi, its principles, its implementation and its responsibilities. Provides and introduction to general management theory in the context of the construction industry.

Planning, operation, maintenance, upgrade and disposal of built assets with an emphasis on the provision of value-for-money to asset owners. Critically evaluates implementation procedures, systems and techniques for built asset management programmes; and provides best practice knowledge that could be applied to a diverse set of assets for their optimal use over their life cycle.

An interdisciplinary approach to the study of defects and performance. Critically evaluates how the structure and materials of a building relate to its environment, its occupants and the way the building is used, to develop a better understanding of building failures. Critically evaluates the systematic investigation of properties and building problems while developing technical skills involved in this core activity of building condition surveying.

The implications of energy use for the design and operation of building services. Critically evaluates the aims, principles and techniques of energy management in buildings. The objective is for students to acquire sufficient understanding of the subject to be able to carry out an energy audit of a building, to advise on the measures necessary to reduce energy consumption, and to assess their cost effectiveness.

Critically evaluates methods of adapting and maintaining modern and historic buildings and develops the necessary technical and design expertise necessary for such work. Develops skills required to maintain buildings, renovate buildings and reconstruct failed components according to code compliance standards.

Modern Methods of Construction. Develops knowledge of the range of technologies available for the construction of commercial and industrial buildings including the construction of substructure, superstructure, in addition to off-site production.

Critically evaluates approaches and tools used in prediction, investigation, intervention design, implementation and evaluation. Explores the role of the Safety Engineer through an analysis of common scenarios and responses.

The key aspects of construction site engineering and management to achieve a positive safety culture in construction and the effective setting up and running of a site. Critically evaluates the occupational health and safety issues, legal responsibilities of the key internal stakeholders and factors involved in the management of construction sites with respect to all primary and secondary stakeholders (community, government, interested parties).

An interdisciplinary project enabling students to experience the challenges that arise from the interactions between design and construction and the professional roles and collaboration within a design context. Students will work collaboratively in interdisciplinary teams to complete an integrative project.
Introduces students to the building blocks found in modern power electronic systems, their operation and design.
Students develop an in-depth understanding of control systems including their analysis and design.
Design and analysis of the critical elements of an electric power system.

Encompases the design and development of complex digital hardware systems, and the design and implementation of complex digital functionality through the use of embedded microprocessors and Field Programmable hardware devices such as FPGA. Applications are developed for embedded microcontroller systems and for FPGA based systems. Students will be able to use appropriate tools to express functional requirements in terms of state transition diagrams and then implement these in VHDL code suitable for direct programming of advanced Field Programmable hardware devices.
To provide the advanced knowledge and skills required for designing building, testing, commissioning and analysing large computer networks.
Software engineering design using object-oriented techniques, UML and design patterns.

Provides an introduction to distributed and alternative electricity generation. The paper covers the reasons behind the drive to these technologies, as well as examining and evaluating the technologies used, including wind, co-gen plants, micro-sites, and system reliability. The design of interconnection issues, system control, and system modelling will be performed.

This module is a supervised final year project that involves the development of the student working as an individual or part of a team. The project requires the student to use existing and develop new skills which include theoretical/practical design and production techniques. The project should be related to the student's major. The student should be able to critically reflect on the relationship between their academic studies and engineering workplace practice, to test theories, identify gaps in their knowledge and to enhance their understanding of practical engineering matters.

Focuses on the commercial environment graduates will be working in and the role of a professional engineer. Topics include strategic planning, business planning, resource management, budgets, risk management, financial management, product development processes and commercialisation. Legal, ethical and sustainability issues are also covered.
To enable coverage of the additional topics in engineering from within the electrical and electronic, mechanical, construction, and software engineering discipline areas.
To enable coverage of the additional topics in engineering from within the electrical and electronic, mechanical, construction, and software engineering discipline areas.

Involves application in a coherent manner of a range of essential engineering knowledge and practices relevant to mechanical engineering design to produce engineering solutions to a prescribed situation.  This includes the detailed design of individual components that make up multi-component, functional mechanical systems as well as fatigue, stress, deflection and critical speeds analysis. The determination of essential characteristics relating to component interrelationships as well as consideration of manufacture, assembly, safety and optimisation are also applied.

To build on previous knowledge of modern manufacturing processes and their application to manufacturing processes and systems. To enable students to understand the concepts and application of quality and reliability of engineering processes and systems. Modern manufacturing processes and their application to manufacturing processes and systems including the concepts and application of quality and reliability of engineering processes and systems.

The theory and operation of control systems, equipment, and strategies used in industrial environments for the measurement and control of common physical parameters (eg pressure, temperature, level and flow). It will also introduce digital techniques and the use of computers in control.

Enables the student to solve complex strength of materials problems as related to failure analysis and theories and the design of beams, columns, cylinders, pressure vessels, shafts, plates and springs.

Explores the relationship between structure and properties of materials under various mechanical loadings and manufacturing environments. Understanding this relationship enables appropriate selection of materials and cost effective manufacturing processes to deliver products to required specifications.

Product Design incorporates elements of Industrial Design and Mechanical Design. In this course students will consider how designs are developed from initial concepts to final working products capable of being manufactured and sold. The emphasis students will take with their projects in this paper could change according to elective papers that they have previously taken. They could concentrate more on the design calculations and theory if they studied the mechanical option. Alternatively if they studied the production option they could concentrate more on the manufacturing aspects.
Provides advanced knowledge of modern manufacturing processes and their application to production engineering.
Builds on previous study to give students a sound grounding in the theory and application of thermodynamics, especially as related to heat engines.

Enables students to investigate a specific industrial problem and develop a creative and appropriate solution. It acts as a focus for integrating prior years of study of the Bachelor of Engineering Technology. Knowledge and skills previously obtained will be utilised in successful completion of this project.

Introduces students to the wonders of the Universe and equips them with the basic concepts and principles of astronomy. Describes and explains cosmic cycles and 'rhythms', the origin of matter and time, formation of galaxies, stars and the Earth. An introduction to the history of astronomy and Maori cosmology will provide an appreciation of the contemporary place of astronomy and a framework for understanding how the modern body of astronomy knowledge has developed.

Skills and capabilities based on theoretical knowledge in the areas of written, oral, interpersonal and group communication. The content of the course is at all stages made relevant to the students needs both for their course of study and their role in the workplace.

An introduction to the basics of computer programming to equip students for a career in any branch of IT, the sciences, data analysis or engineering. The fundamentals of writing, designing and testing programs will be developed.
Introduces the process of program design and implementation using object-oriented programming, with particular emphasis on applications from Computer Science and engineering technology.

Presents an integrated approach to data communications and computer networking principles, building on IT infrastructure concepts. These concepts are applied in a network environment starting with the application layer and progressing through to the data link layer.

Introduces programming concepts through the use of structured scripting to move and manipulate multimedia objects, such as images, audio and video files. Aspects of interpreting system feedback, identifying errors and developing coding best practice are also covered.  This elective paper provides students with an opportunity to learn and practice programming through structured activities that can be built on in more advanced programming papers.

Overview of important contemporary computer concepts, including machine architecture and function, software applications and data organisation, including applications such as spreadsheets and databases.
Introduces the process of program design and implementation using object-oriented programming, with particular emphasis on applications from Computer Science and engineering technology.
Introduces the process of program design and implementation using object-oriented programming, with particular emphasis on applications from Computer Science and engineering technology.

Provides an introduction to the mathematical concepts required for an understanding of the analysis of data and applications in computing, science, and engineering. Topics include: sets, functions, series, limits, calculus, probability and statistics.
Gives the student an understanding of differential and integral calculus, and develops the ability to formulate and solve models of simple engineering and scientific systems.

Gives the student a solid foundation in algebra and discrete mathematics, providing essential background for further study in many fields of Science and Engineering, particularly those utilizing ideas from Mathematics or Computer Science.

A general, calculus-based classical physics course. The topics covered are: particle kinematics, Newtonian dynamics, work and energy, gravitation, collisions and momentum, torque and angular momentum, rigid-body statics and dynamics, harmonic oscillations, mechanical waves, sound waves, thermal processes, laws of thermodynamics, entropy.

An introduction to applied statistics. Provides techniques for describing and summarising a data set. Delivers an understanding of how to use a sample to infer the properties of the population it was taken from. Students in this course also learn how to use statistical software to undertake descriptive analysis as well as perform statistical inference.

The techniques of spherical trigonometry will be applied to the analysis of problems of positional astronomy. Topics include coordinate systems and their transformations, parallax, precession and aberration, sidereal time, time-keeping and calendar, as well as the basics of celestial mechanics such as Kepler's laws, two-body orbital motion, and binary star orbits. The paper emphasises computational aspects of spherical (positional) astronomy.

The fundamental concepts and principles of astrophysics are examined developing an understanding of and problem solving skills in radioactive processes, stellar structures and evolution, physics of the Solar System, galactic structure and evolution, and cosmology.

An introduction to the design and construction of object- oriented software. It will extend individual design and programming skills developed in earlier programming papers, with an emphasis on the quality, modularity and reusability of the software developed. The paper will introduce current techniques used in software development that allow the goals of software development projects to be realised.

An introduction to the design and construction of object- oriented software. It will extend individual design and programming skills developed in earlier programming papers, with an emphasis on the quality, modularity and reusability of the software developed. The paper will introduce current techniques used in software development that allow the goals of software development projects to be realised.

Theoretical and practical skills for the utilisation of mathematical structures and algorithms for handling data that are essential in computational mathematics and computer science. Static and dynamic structures for data, cloning data, mathematical concepts of iteration and recursion, analysis of performance and complexity, data searching and data sorting algorithms, mathematical logic and formal grammars.
Algorithmic analysis, concurrency algorithms, design patterns, design techniques, advanced data structures, graph algorithms, numerical algorithms.

A practical foundation in high-level computer graphics programming and a comprehensive overview of proven graphics algorithms and software techniques is presented with a focus on those techniques that have become common currency in the field of interactive computer graphics.
An introduction to the logical and combinatorial tools and methods used in mathematics and computer science, with an emphasis on axiomatic systems, combinatorial principles, and automated reasoning.

Provides students with the essential concepts, principles, and techniques of database management systems. Specifically, the paper provides an in-depth understanding of data modelling and database design concepts. The retrieval language will be covered in detail. The balanced approach of theory and practice will provide students with a better understanding of the issues and problems involved in database design and development.
Provides the student with a solid foundation in linear algebra and its applications.
Gives the student a solid understanding of advanced calculus, and develops the ability to formulate and solve models of complex engineering and scientific systems.
A foundation in linear algebra. Solving and applying ordinary, partial and systems of differential equations.
The elements of actuarial mathematics: securities, annuities, mortality laws, life annuities, life insurance policy values.

A calculus-based general physics paper. The topics covered include: Electro- and magnetostatics, DC and AC circuits, time-varying fields, Maxwell's equations, electromagnetic waves, geometric optics, interference and diffraction, the quantum nature of particles and light, atomic and nuclear phenomena.

Provides an introduction to a branch of statistics that deals with the study of chance. Delivers access to a range of techniques for modelling and analysing probability problems in real-life settings.
A study of statistical methods suitable for a range of applications in science, engineering and business.
Development of awareness of the philosophies of Quality Management; statistical and organisational techniques for establishing, maintaining and improving quality.

An introduction to forecasting in business and economics using statistical models. Making predictions from data that arise sequentially in time (e.g. annual electricity production, unemployment rates, share prices, global temperature series). Topics include forecasting strategies, detecting trends, autoregressive models, and simulation.

The principles and practice of observational astronomy and astrophysics with a focus on the design and synthesis of instruments for specific observational programmes. Topics include telescopes (including optical and radio), multi-wavelength radiation detectors, gravitational and neutrino detectors, methods of CCD photometry and astrometry, principles and methods of spectroscopy and astronomical data analysis techniques, .polarimetry, magnetometry and solar observational techniques.

Provides an understanding of the principles and practice of Radio Astronomy starting from a review of the radio astronomical Universe: the Sun and planets, gaseous nebulae, pulsars, masers, radio galaxies and quasars and cosmic microwave background radiation. Topics include radio spectroscopy, the design of radio telescopes and the application of interferometric techniques to the analysis of synthesis imaging

Examines different aspects of modern astronomy and astrophysics by surveying topics that are at the cutting edge of current research. Topics include microarcsecond astrometry, numerical and quantum cosmology, microlensing, exoplanets, active galactic nuclei and relativistic jets, X-ray and Gamma-ray astronomy, dark matter and dark energy, pulsars and magnetars, SETI, optical and radio telescopes of the future.
A practical foundation in game programming, using a variety of game development tools and programming libraries, and deploying games on a variety of platforms.

A rigorous exploration into the Theory of Computer Science providing a mathematically sound presentation of the theory of computer science including formal languages and models of computation, as well as an introduction to computational complexity.
Surveys the theoretical and practical aspects of modern programming languages, including their design and implementation, program translation, virtual machines, and different programming pradigms.
Investigates the design and implementation of distributed systems, including contemporary technologies such as Java Enterprise Edition and .NET, as well as the development of mobile systems.
Provides an in-depth understanding of LAN, WAN and Wireless security focusing on the functionality available and configuration of network and link layers.
The aim of this paper is to understand the nature of intelligent systems and how such a system may be implemented.
Furthers understanding of the factors (psychological, ergonomic, organisational, social etc) that determine how people operate and make use of computer technology effectively.

Introduces students to the exciting world of Data Mining. Organisations have, over time, accumulated vast amounts of valuable data which, when exploited appropriately will give them a significant competitive advantage over their rivals who merely "crunch" data. Data Mining is an area that has come of age - well proven techniques and tools are widely available. Covers popular mining techniques as well as providing specific hands-on experience using a publicly available tool.

This paper aims to further develop your understanding of the concepts and methods required for the construction of large software intensive systems. The paper develops a broader understanding of the discipline of software engineering to provide exposure to the full range of techniques and processes associated with the development of complex software intensive systems.
Advanced mathematical models in the areas of financial mathematics. Apply mathematical concepts and analytic techniques to solve financial, engineering and/or industrial problems.
To enable coverage of the mathematical sciences in the areas of applied mathematics, analytics, astronomy or computer science.
To permit further concentration on new emergent topics in the mathematical sciences on areas of special staff expertise or research interests.
Develops skills in the interpretation and use of numerical methods appropriate to engineering and science, and in the development of computer programs using numerical techniques.
Investigates linear partial differential equations in one, two, and three dimensions, including analytic techniques for solving partial differential equations and their applications.
An investigation into a scientific problem where the student develops skills in experimental design; literature searching; the collection, treatment, interpretation and reporting of results.

Students will use mathematical theories and techniques to solve problems in business, engineering and physical sciences. Using software, such as MatLab and R, to apply and verify the models will be an integral part of the paper.
A one semester international exchange for students studying mathematical sciences.

The focus of this paper is the application of stochastic models to analyse real-life scenarios.  Key stochastic processes are studied via their mathematical properties and simulation. Models are fitted to data taken from a range of applications.

An introduction to data management for analytics suitable for applications in business, finance, industry, and government.  Topics include: querying, cleaning, manipulating, and displaying data;   programming skills and methods suitable for handling large data sets.
Collection and analysis of data in an industrial and business context. Control charts, experimental design, samples and surveys. Analysis of data using analytics software.

qualification_name: Graduate Certificate in Computer and Information Sciences
prescriptor: Language and vision are fundamental to human perception and cognition, yet there is relatively little understanding of how the two interact or operate together at a system level to aid learning and recognition. This paper covers fundamental and advanced aspects of language (especially text) and vision from an artificial intelligence perspective. The primary focus is on practical algorithms, tools and systems of text, vision intelligence, as well as their performance evaluation. Techniques of representing information in semi-formal languages such as Standard Generalized Markup Language (SGML) and free text are compared. The issues associated with representation and extraction of information encapsulated in textual and visual formats, such as the semantic unit perceived as an event, will be explored. Examples of text and visual modelling techniques such as probabilistic and vector models will be used to illustrate AI applications.
